justifications: Instead, the "Leave" side - which railed against European regulations and increased migration in a heated campaign battle - was celebrating their triumph.
"Remain" campaigners had argued a Brexit would be disastrous for the British and even global economy - but the result showed voters were unswayed.
The EU now finds itself in uncharted waters: No nation state has ever left the bloc.
The leaders of the EU institutions urged Britain to act quickly to formalize its exit "however painful that process may be."
"We have our country back," tweeted U.K. Independence Party leader Nigel Farage, a key figure in the "Leave" campaign.
He later told reporters the referendum was "a victory for ordinary people, against the big banks, big business and big politics."

"I did not want us to go out on a kind of anti-immigration, negative agenda."
